awd_titl_txt: Computational Approaches to Biological Ion Channel Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Rob Coalson of the University of Pittsburgh is supported by an award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program for research to develop computational methods for the simulation of ion channel dynamics.  The work builds on the PI's previous successful work to now include problems involving the mechanisms of ion channel gating, the transport of small solute molecules through protein channels and other basic aspects of signal transduction in proteins.

The structure and function of ion channel proteins represents the frontier of knowledge in biological science. Ion channels and pumps are essential for a wide range of physiological function, from nerve signal propagation, to muscle contraction, to autoregulation of cell volume, to production of biochemicals like insulin, to memory acquisition and consciousness. Malfunction of ion channels is therefore implicated as the root cause of many serious diseases and neuropsychiatric disorders, including arrhythmias, seizure disorders, panic attacks, glaucoma, hypertension, renal disease, cystic fibrosis, certain types of epilepsy and migraine headaches. Approximately 1/3 of all drugs on the market today target ion channels. The knowledge of how ion channels function has enormous potential for correcting or replacing defective channels in the body.  This work is, thus, expected to have an enormously broad impact on a wide variety of biologically relevant topics.  In addition to the scientific broader impacts, the impact of the research is further broadened by Coalson's work with the Telluride workshops and the creation of a Summer Institute focused on computational biology.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_txt_cntn:
Ion channel proteins are essential for a wide range of physiological function, from nerve signal propagation, to muscle contraction, to auto-regulation of cell volume, to production of biochemicals like insulin, to memory acquisition and consciousness.  Malfunction of ion channels is therefore implicated as the root cause of many serious diseases, including arrhythmias, seizure disorders, hypertension, renal disease, cystic fibrosis, certain types of epilepsy and migraine headaches. Approximately 1/3 of all drugs on the market today target ion channels.  
       Another intriguing class of biological nanopores, Nuclear Pore Complexes (NPCs), is comprised of large protein complexes which span the nuclear envelope in eukaryotic cells.   Since proteins and RNAs pass through the NPC pore, malfunction of NPCs is associated with serious diseases such as cancer.  The size and complexity of NPCs present major challenges to molecular modeling analysis.
      Under the auspices of this NSF grant, we have made major strides in developing novel phsico-chemically based computation algorithms for understanding the relationship between structure and biologically important function in both ion channels and NPCs.  In addition we have developed insightful semi-analytic models for studying both equilibrium and nonequilibrium properties of these systems.  Our findings will influence not only the course of basic science in these areas but also applications to medicine and nanotechnology.
